PgNlAW4wxQhaiN7X894FVw.text: Came for the afternoon tea. The teas were excellent. And all the baked goods were delicious, especially the scones. It's located in a shopping mall. Make a reservation ahead of time for afternoon tea! We didn't realize you had to do so, but the waitress was kind enough to squeeze us in. However, if we had come in 10 minutes later, there was no way she could have. Very friendly staff. Great time!

GicHDCNsEHxZigi5oTSJbQ.text: I love the decor here! The restaurant is very cute and comfortable, with plush chairs and prettily arranged tea towers It's a great deal for afternoon tea service. The staff are very friendly and helpful, and the pastries were delicious. My favorite were the cupcakes (nutella and carrot cake) and the white chocolate brownie bites. The scones were ok, great with jam and clotted cream but needed some fruit baked into them to really give them flavor. We like a lot of toppings on our scones and had to fight over the small bit of jam they brought for the two of us to share. The sandwiches were good but made on mini baguettes, which was sad because I was hoping for traditional delicate finger sandwiches on thin bread. But they did taste good.My only real issue was that the cutlery could have been a lot cleaner cleaner - this is a big sticking point with me, so  the fact that they still get 4 stars after this shows you just how great the tea service was overall! Well, that and I wish they'd given us milk or cream for the tea.So, in the end, if you just want tea and a scone,  they're probably tastier at the Jubilee Cafe at Westminster palace (if you can get there), but this was a full tea service and includes so many great things, I'd definitely recommend it. And come hungry! This tea service is really a full meal, so have it instead of lunch or dinner.

rPWiLEw6NSQt0Hj6hd-E8g.text: I went here for my last tea in London and absolutely love this charming little tea house! The décor is eccentric and bright, with teapot shaped lights strung throughout the room. I went to the One New Change location that is right around the corner from Saint Paul's. Beas is lovely and offers up a huge and delicious afternoon tea for a modest £15. The tea is complete with a cupcake of your choice (you can choose from red velvet, chocolate, tiramisu among others), meringues, brownies, blondies, fresh baked scones with clotted cream and jam, and 3 different types of savory sandwiches. Talk about a bang for your buck. The people were just as charming as the restaurant and have real pride about their products. I love it here and am sad that I have to leave London so soon!

YafwtWCh5Lf3FPB3lyptng.text: Love love love the newest Bea's. Popped in there for a hot drink on Saturday evening, so there weren't too many cakes and assorted baked goods left. Much to my delight, we got a table right at the corner in the upstairs seating area, which allowed us to people watch. There were quite a few people who just stopped dead in their tracks and came up to the window display to gawk at all the pretty cakes. The decor remains very much in line with the original over at Bloomsbury (duh). I love how the seat cushions bear the same pattern but come in different colours so that they meld in some kind of joyously understated harmony. Did I just write that? Well, it's merely because I really do like their decor. On the food front, the brownie was just as good as at the original shop while the espresso and whiskey bundt cake was delicious if a little too large for just me. I was a little disappointed that my flat white didn't come with any latte art. I know it's not a measure of coffee quality, but I've become accustomed to a little rosetta or heart adorning my coffees!

wzhyxPdP5hxEx9jjKJmyOw.text: What do you do when you find yourself in the vicinity of Bank during the weekend and want to relax with a spot of tea? There aren't really that many choices as most shops here are catered for the office crowd and closed during the weekend. Thankfully, Bea's opened their second branch in the no longer new shopping place known as One New Change. Definitely a welcome sight, the place here has more space to accommodate diners than the original. It doesn't have the relaxed intimate atmosphere of its original but still emits a cool urban vibe. We settled to relax and both ordered a cupcake and a drink. I could not help ordering the hot chocolate with a dash of alcohol and since it's the weekend, why not? I've always enjoyed the sweet treats from Bea's and this was no exception. With alcohol and sugary delights in me, I left happily heading to meet up with some friends. If you happen to be looking for a cafe when you're around the area, try popping in here. The price is hiked up slightly compared to the original but comes as no surprise considering the area it is in.

mGxtKOzs0MpwWprvv-YBtw.text: Two friends and I had a lovely, delicious lunch here the other day. The service was quick and friendly, and the food was really good. I had an amazing chicken and avocado sandwich, but also tasted my friend's chicken soup, which was some of the best I've tasted. I wish we'd had time (and appetite) for a dessert because the cakes looked great. This is a great place for a city lunch hour. They're quick, they're friendly, the food is good and the decor is lovely and colourful. Much better than one of the endless pizza chains in the area.

LDAf6c56Md3QgHwsPFqc0Q.text: I've been to Bea's twice now. The first time was for a quick lunch a few months ago and the salad I ordered was divine - a lovely combination of yummy savouries. So after a shopping trip in One New Change this week, I brought my friend to Bea's for lunch, insisting it was fantastic. The display of cakes at Bea's is amazing, all sorts of colours and shapes, with brownies, cupcakes and macaroons piled invitingly high. It didn't start well when there was no savoury food (at lunch), wasn't quite sure why but we decided just to have two cakes instead to make up for it! We ordered coffee and I had a brownie and my friend ordered a double chocolate cupcake. My capuccino was more like a latte and I popped some sugar in and stirred and then took a sip. What followed was the most acrid, bitter drink I have ever tasted. My friend had the same experience with her black americano which was completely undrinkable. Her cupcake was dry, with the frosting "the texture of wet cement, that didn't taste like chocolate" and my brownie was dry and crumbly and I gave up half way through. There was a mutual agreement NOT to try a second cake. We decided to leave and went to the counter to pay. At no point had we been asked if everything was ok and I presumed the question would be asked at the till, as the table had since been cleared as it was obvious there was a problem with two full coffees just left. No. There were 4 members of staff at the counter and each walked past us a couple of times until after a few minutes, someone decided to serve us. Our payment was taken, we were thanked and that was it!The staff were perfectly nice, but young and very clearly disinterested in helping ensure better customer service. So disappointed. Won't be going back.

brVE0pbjNmqDC6qIKaDuOw.text: I have been a regular here since Bea's New Change branch opened a couple of years ago.  I was delighted when it arrived as previously there was only Starbucks/Costa etc to choose from.  The draw remains the cakes whether in cupcake form or otherwise they are delicious and feel like a decadent treat whenever purchased.  However, the coffee is extremely variable in quality depending on who the barrista is that day, lurching from burnt espresso one day to a macchiato on another which was essentially a latte given the amount of milk that had been added to it.  Still when the cakes are this good, having sub-par coffee almost doesn't matter.

7uBgyxn89-cEY7XuAGNtoA.text: I was really excited about trying this place and after stepping into the tea world of Bea, I was even more excited about the wonderful delights that I could try. I was craving a freshly made scone with some clotted cream and lots of jam. So I quickly ordered one of those, I'm disappointed to say that the scone was rock solid hard. It felt anything but fresh. Don't get me wrong, the cream and the jam were indeed tasty (even the decor of the tea parlour was done brilliantly, with lots of lovely sunlight streaming through) however the scone was a massive let down for me. I'm in no hurry to be heading back to this place.

q-BBYazNR1S0RUbJlOFsGg.text: This is the recently opened location at One New Change right by St. Paul's. Oh wow... I could eat these scones all day long, delish! The afternoon tea comes with a choice of sandwiches, scone with clotted cream and jelly, blondie, brownie, cupcake, heavenly homemade marshmallow, meringue, sugar cookie as well as a choice of teas. I had the English Breakfast Assam which was fab. The decor is cute, the lighting upstairs is a series of lighted tea pots and the upholstery was modern, chic and homey all at the same time. Our waitress was very friendly, attentive and took our order on an iPad. We even bought some additional goodies for the hotel. Love it. I will be back on my next visit to London.

spAM6PBfJNehqjICRv305g.text: I came here for afternoon tea on Tuesday with a friend and while the food was decent, especially the scones and clotted cream, the service was slower than snail's pace. Not only that, they served us our goodies on a broken cake stand. When we were leaving we were so disappointed that, my friend actually declined a chance to win a vocher for 150 pounds for the restaurant, saying that she wouldn't come back even for a million bucks.

gRDRgCQYLogGDB9X42Ybag.text: We called in on our way to Tate Modern. They don't serve savoury food at the weekends (except with the expensive afternoon teas) so we stuck to coffees and cakes. These were delicious, particularly the chocolate and Guinness cake. All in all, not a bad place.

QrTw8HLUITUVZUWCkAFZPg.text: Took my cousins here when they were visiting for afternoon tea. You have to book ahead to reserve a spot for the full afternoon tea (£19/person), and it'll get you an assortment of savoury snacks and heaps of sweets - so much that we couldn't finish it all! It's a small location - tea's are had upstairs, but from what I know you can also have cake and tea downstairs if you're looking to just pop in for a nibble.  Overall it was a fun experience - I know people love their cupcakes but I found them to be a bit too sweet. The scones however were delish!

QFdngGIdL5eWm7svZfs4DQ.text: Cute lil coffee shop and bakery. Lovely and huge cup cakes!! They do big cakes too, but they're reasonably expensive, so be aware if they're your last minute option for birthday cakes to take into the office!!! (Been burnt by that before!)

aWHBjlolcI4GVNJfKALbQQ.text: Bea's gets full pretty quickly.  Going in during lunch for takeaway, I'm in line with people waiting for tables, which does make the wait a bit long sometimes.What I love:Duffins (doughnut muffins whaaat) filled with jam, passionfruit cheesecake with meringue, meringues with pistachio or passion fruit inside, banana bread with streusel on top.What I'm meh about:The salads and quiche and sandwiches.  They're okay, but it's nothing remarkable.  I do like for a box of 5 quid, you can pick a variety of salads (ranging from cauliflower salad to beet salad to caesar) to jam in.Never tried their cupcakes but it looks like they have an assortment of flavors.

rAuOw-cnv3Tjy0PvenmTRQ.text: I rarely give out 5 stars, so for Beas of Bloomsbury to receive such a high ranking must mean it's something special!I came here to celebrate my recent promotion (yay me!) and heard about this place through a friend. I checked it out online and saw that reservations can only be made via e-mail. However, after no response, we just gave them a call and they were fine to reserve it on the phone. I loved the look of it - shabby chic meets art deco. I especially loved all the little details, such as the little Buddha who held the reservation card up high on my table. I ordered afternoon tea with a pot of lychee black tea. Our afternoon tea came with a mix of small sized baguettes, cupcakes, meringues, and other gorgeous treats I do not know the name of! But OOOH EM GEE - The scones were to die for! The best I've ever had. To top it off, the staff were friendly and efficient. I'm definitely going to come back here again and again and again...

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

J3bxz6qyGh__UN_aYlrpKQ.text: It almost seems strange that for not the first time, I've sat down to write reviews and found one of my regular stops on the list that still hasn't been reviewed after living in London for over three months. Beas is one of those stops, a necessary tea and pastry stop in the overwhelmed business school world I now call my life.I love that they offer afternoon tea, that they have sugar bowls on every table.I love the cupcakes, including the blue cookie monster ones on Halloween which dyed my mouth blue.I love the pastries, fluffy and light, or decadent and too-rich-for-breakfast (but perfect for curing a mid-class hangover).I love the Thanksgiving dinner, offering us expats a welcome taste of home with friendly service and a good price.I've obviously celebrated holidays at Beas. I trust them to give me good food when I most miss things from home. The atmosphere is quirky yet so comfortable that I love to pop in. I certainly have no plans of stopping my tea and pastry study breaks and meetings now.

yKOA_1JnJRGh2MbovIhB8Q.text: Now, you may know from my previous reviews that i'm a meat lover, meat, meat, meat all day long, but after a couple of hours being dragged around the One New Change by my wife, enough was enough, I needed a pick me up.  So we come across this little beaut,  it was quite busy so we waited about 10 minutes for a table,  I ordered a cappuccino and a Chocolate Peanut Butter cheesecake, we took our seats upstairs and took in the scenery which was nice and cosy, loved all the decor. So onto the thing that really matters, the cake and the coffee, the cake was absolutely  delicious, the best cheesecake I have ever tasted and the coffee was very pleasant, all of a sudden I had forgotten about the shops i've waited outside of, a very nice chilled experience, can't wait to try more of there delicious cakes.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate Peanut Butter Cheesecake
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter cheese cake thingy, with a lovely Cappuccino

cpE0ZWMhQ3TLByDq2bVE1A.text: I was disappointed, after reading reviews and wanting to go here for a while. Firstly, for a a cafe that proclaimed it's won accolades for afternoon tea to be served a tea bag in a pot is very poor. quality. Also the waitress mixed up my Earl Grey tea with my friends English Breakfast, which we didn't realise until we started drinking the tea. We didn't try any of the cakes. I won't be rushing back their in a hurry.

8jG6fwP-BrKMRHX6dobbXg.text: Came here for the £17 afternoon tea for my birthday. I booked online about 5 days beforehand as it seemed like the most reasonable priced afternoon tea around central London. When we went in, we saw empty seats but were told there was no space, before telling them we had a reservation. So make sure you book in advance!! We were seated promptly upstairs. I was glad as downstairs looked quite cramped. Our server was really bubbly, wishing me happy birthday, and brought us out our sandwiches and tea right away.The sandwiches were good, but I'd made a request saying that one of the parties was vegetarian, so they brought out 3 vegetarian and 3 meat. The meat ones had brie, which I hate! The platter of treats came out like a mirage though, serious sugar overload! There was a cupcake each - a caramel one and one with blueberries on top, marshmallows, meringues, a scone with clotted cream and jam each, and samples of 3 different types of brownie (so yum!). I had the Dragon Green Tea which was lovely, and the tea replenishment was free. I wish you could've had a choice of your main cupcake though!The seating should have been 1 1/2 hours but we cut it down to an hour as had somewhere else to be.It was a bargain for the price, I'd do it again...would you?!

JPUUpIbMHUdkY3W4AiAX6Q.text: Give me something slightly savory, with a golden-brown crust and a soft, buttery crumb. Then, spread it with sweet, fresh jam followed by a generous swipe of clotted cream. Order matters. This is the epitome of a proper British scone, and it's just what Bea's of Bloomsbury serves up, alongside other indulgent cakes, meringues, brownies and other butter-laden pastries. There's no shortage of carbs or fat here, and I wouldn't want it any other way.

zfXI93kl2ZJ4iW3GEgRw2g.text: I actually think they put crack in their scones, clotted cream and jam. Seriously. So, I went here for high tea with my girlfriends and we had a nice time. The food was fantastic, the server was super forgetful but incredibly sweet. I suppose the only reason I can't give them five stars is because the only toilet wasn't flushing properly and there was no soap in the bathroom. I mean, if the only bathroom has no soap, then what are *employees* doing to keep their hands clean?!

phIyGA_BWir3IJfbgZ4kOg.text: I took my mum here with my sister for Mother's Day and it was a really enjoyable experience. One whole side of the wall is glass looking out over St. Paul's and as it was a beautiful day this was a lovely view! The front counter is full of delicious looking cakes and pastries and the staff had already prepared our table when we arrived as I had already booked. We had the afternoon tea which was a selection of sandwiches, scones with cream and jam, brownies and cupcakes which were absolutely a-mazing. I highly recommend the 'blondies' which were little white chocolate brownies. The whole place had a slightly Alice in Wonderland feel which was pretty cool. The sugar cup was actually a little bath with 'sugar?' written on the side and the cake stand had 'eat me' written on it too. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone, especially for meals with the mother!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

0OeV83V4hIE7Ktqh1HVUTA.text: I am a huge Bea's fan (I used to frequent the one in Bloomsbury for lunch) and this time I was in New Change for a meeting and went for the cuppy cake!  Yummers!  I was very pleased with the moist and light texture of the red velvet and the delicious frosting.  It was delectable.  They also do a nice square mile latte.  Loved our 2 person seat on the main floor by the window (great for people watching).  I didn't check out the upstairs, but seemed like there was ample seating.  An elegant place for a coffee meeting and great desserts.  (And I am sure they do a fab lunch like the Bloomsbury locale).  I heart you Bea's!

enoeW7lPnTaPR51fbrJ4kQ.text: I was rather excited to hear that there would be a branch of the fabulous Bea's in One New Change, the City's newest shopping 'destination'. I decided to treat myself on this miserable Friday and pop over to Bea's for my lunch. The shop is rather small, but in no way cramped. I had a delicious baguette from the selection (although I spend ages eyeing up the array of salad stuffs - I can feel a repeat visit coming on!). It makes a real change from the plastic pre-wrapped sandwiches in my staff canteen! I also had one of the cupcakes - and oh wow! The sponge was delicious (not the lightest I've ever had, but in no way stodgy) and the icing - melt in the mouth amazing! Go on, treat yourself!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

VCmQG6JLoBrwByXeoiHpTw.text: Where do you take your dessert-loving visiting friend for a quintessential, albeit sweet heavy, afternoon tea? Why Bea's of Bloomsbury of course. On a quiet Monday afternoon my friend and I enjoyed some dessert with a side of afternoon tea. Seriously skip your lunch because you will want to save room for your mashmallow, meringue, macaron, brownie bite, cupcake and scone. Oh yeah there's some mini baguettes but life's too short to waste stomach space on boring bread.My only wish is that you were able to choose your cupcake. While my friend and I were duly impressed with our vanilla and chocolate option, the lemon and red velvet looked equally amazing. A full afternoon tea will set you back 15 pounds, but it's worth it for a special occasion. I find it's good value for money for a nice afternoon tea as a comparable quality option in central London would run you at least 30 pounds.

H6_SwOllkLQRPssvE-1oQw.text: A really nice afternoon tea in cosy surroundings (highly recommend getting a reservation). The sweets are far better than the savoury options which were a bit lacking - the sandwiches weren't well presented but they did taste okay. I did receive off milk and the service was a bit surly (I got asked if I was sure about the milk...erm, yeah). Overall though had a nice few hours here catching up with friends and the cupcakes really were divine.

TX_K_gs9RLkvMfQdZcJq-w.text: I do not get the fuss over Bea's. I've been twice this year, once in Jan with a large group, and this time with a girlfriend the past weekend in September. Service is definitely 'surly,' to quote another reviewer. In January, they asked us to leave the table (before we'd quite finished) because they had another table coming in, and then started cleaning up while we were still eating. This time, the person running the register seemed as if he wanted to do ANYTHING but welcome us. Perhaps it was because we dared to ask for high tea without a reservation? The man behind the counter (young man, short blond hair) wordlessly pointed at the sign that says 'reservations recommended.' So...that's a no? And then he ignored us as if that was the end of the interaction. We asked another person behind the counter (a man with what we think was a French accent) if we could get a cream tea, and he helpfully offered to see if they had any scones left. He came back with four scones and placed our order, but it still took 25 minutes to get our food on the table. We saw people who'd ordered after us get all of their food, and we sat there, expectant, hopeful expressions, and waited and waited. Just odd. Yes, the scones were good, but it's London! There are plenty of spots to find decent scones and tea. I won't be back for a third visit at Bea's.

3vIyHrGrGY3z28QOyLr6zg.text: Enjoyed the mini-meringues, cute retail space, and friendly staff but the One New Change location disappoints for cupcakes. Cake was inedible- a dense soggy mess, although raspberry frosting was just ok. Seating in upstairs booths felt pedestrian - and a bit uncomfortable. Their champagne afternoon tea was perfunctory, with Moet & a very small scone when compared to champagne teas in other shopping malls ( ie. the cafe at Selfridges) for relatively similar prices.

b_AZckd-I4VgctR7yjU60w.text: I like Bea's, I like Bea's a lot. Wasn't expecting the 30 minute wait for a seat on a Monday afternoon (I suppose it was tea time, though), but I got through it and had a rather delicious reward at the end.The St. Paul's branch of Bea's, tucked away in an unassuming corner of One New Change shopping centre, is significantly smaller than the other two locations. The sheer lack of table space is probably why my friend and I had to wait, in the first place. They do take reservations  (although I'm not sure whether only for a full afternoon tea, or also for general dessert and coffee consumption), so maybe I will try to do that next time I get a cupcake craving.The decor of the restaurant is very cute, with tea-related prints on the wall and teapot-shaped lanterns covering each lightbulb that hangs from the ceiling. Adorable, indeed!The real reasons for this review are the following:1) The cupcake and dessert display in the front of the shop made me want to salivate like a Pavlovian dog, and roll around in the desserts not quite like a Pavlovian dog, but maybe another type of dog who likes to roll around in cupcakes and lemon squares. Anyway, they were laid out so beautifully (and bountifully) in the display case, and it took my friend and me the entire 30 minutes we were waiting to decide what we'd get. The cupcake choices were virtually endless: chocolate frosting on vanilla, vanilla frosting on chocolate, vanilla on vanilla, chocolate on chocolate, red velvet, Bailey's frosting on chocolate, raspberry vanilla, peanut butter and jelly, hazelnut chocolate (you're getting really tired of me listing these cupcakes, aren't you? But I'm not at all tired of remembering them). And then there were the cakes proper, cheesecakes, and other dessert bars, the latter of which included a curious-looking peanut butter and jelly bar, lemon squares, and millionaire's squares. There wasn't even a question about getting the red velvet. Sorted. However, we were having major issues with the second thing, because there was so bloody much to choose from. In the end, both being American, and having grown up on peanut butter and jelly (not like the gelatine-based stuff, jam) sandwiches, we thought the peanut butter and jelly bar would be a good choice. 2) The peanut butter and jelly bar was probably the best choice I have made in weeks. With a shortbread crust, layers of peanut butter and strawberry jam, and a streusel crumble topping, the dessert just screamed 'I'm going to make it so that you don't fit into any of  your clothing, ever again.' As you, proverbially, only live once, I said 'sod it' right back to the little slice of clogged arteries and went right on with it. The red velvet cupcake also did not disappoint, as it was moist, rich, just chocolate enough, and had the perfect frosting-to-cake ratio. I also liked that there was a bit of whipping cream added to the frosting, rather than just cream cheese and butter, as it made the whole thing less dense (but probably not any healthier). Price points are as expected - we paid £11 odd for the two desserts, along with an Americano and a latte. Couldn't do it every day, but for a nice, weekday pick-me-up, Bea's certainly does the trick.

zg1Zb_kkPNmf2nIzX1F25A.text: I love cupcakes. I love brownies. I love dainty little sandwiches and j'adore champagne at noon. Most of all, I like it done with a bit of style and a bit of flair. Bea's of Bloomsbury delivered at their newest location in St. Paul's. A champagne tea isn't the cheapest thing one can do during a weekend, but I went as a special going-away do and it was fabulous. The waiters were prompt, the service was great, and the cupcakes were to.die.for., served on a platter that had two women's legs sticking up in the air. Fabulous.On the weekends, make a reservation early (preferably during the week before) to ensure you get a spot because it's hugely popular from what I saw.

4w0T9YjY-J-SOeC2ECOmHw.text: What do you do when you find yourself in the vicinity of Bank during the weekend and want to relax with a spot of tea? There aren't really that many choices as most shops here are catered for the office crowd and closed during the weekend. Thankfully, Bea's opened their second branch in the no longer new shopping place known as One New Change. Definitely a welcome sight, the place here has more space to accommodate diners than the original. It doesn't have the relaxed intimate atmosphere of its original but still emits a cool urban vibe. We settled to relax and both ordered a cupcake and a drink. I could not help ordering the hot chocolate with a dash of alcohol and since it's the weekend, why not?I've always enjoyed the sweet treats from Bea's and this was no exception. With alcohol and sugary delights in me, I left happily heading to meet up with some friends. If you happen to be looking for a cafe when you're around the area, try popping in here. The price is hiked up slightly compared to the original but comes as no surprise considering the area it is in.

VsekJS0lFJz_uv67hsGi3g.text: Arrived early for our high tea reservation and were granted a fairly immediate table(the requested table near the window upstairs. We went in March at 3 PM and the sun was blinding and hot and the shades were drawn. Lesson learned. Ha! Service was fabulous and we loved our experience. Each person gets their own tea choice and tea pot. We had green and black currant teas. The black currant was the best tea I have ever had! I am salivating at the thought right now. They kept our pots filled, upon request and lumps of sugar are on the table.The food was very good as well. The scones, in particular, were killer. The sandwiches were all on focaccia bread and consisted of: a fresh moz and caramelized onion, cream cheese and nut mixture and prosciutto and cheese. The bread was just okay but mixtures good. There were blondies, brownies, merengue and two cupcakes(strawberry and chocolate peanut butter). Come on an empty stomach and with good company because you will be there awhile with a large amount of food. Great experience and if we cross the pond again, we would love to go back. Close to St. Paul's, a mall and bus and train lines as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Cute lights made from teapots
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Yummy tri-tiered platter of goodies with high tea

nudeqMdyf575_4nFltmFjg.text: I was in town for only a few days and I was worried that I wouldn't get to experience Tea time in London. Luckily they were able to give us a reservation here on the same day!! Amazing service!! As soon as we walked in I felt the welcoming environment.. Amazing Tea and yummy treats!! We also had a great view of St Pauls Cathedral!! For my first experience at a Tea party it was a great one!! It was tea for two and we each paid $38.17 :)

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

7weCKLfCFFnkGBIRHOAlOg.text: Booked for afternoon tea on a Saturday, once we got there it wasn't too busy until 45 minutes in it got packed. Suddenly we were asked to leave even though they told us we had a 2 hour slot for afternoon tea because they needed the space for customers waiting outside.We were rushed to finish what we had left and told to leave the booth to pay downstairs.This all came down to bad booking management.

Q2KMmDr5A9X5uGKFWEPhyg.text: Small tea and baked goods shop near St Paul Cathedral. Ordered an English breakfast tea (very good, of course) and Duffin with jam. Didn't like the jam, but perhaps this American hasn't developed the English palate. The shop itself is small, with limited seating in and outdoor. We took ours to go to eat on a bench within good view of the Cathedral. It is our understanding that Beas of Bloomsbury is of repute due to an influence on the Seattle-based mega chain Starbucks. Our visit was to satisfy curiosity of what the fuss was about. We still aren't truly sure about the fuss, but it was certainly fine enough.

Qm1z11sytAnK-I9E8I7EEQ.text: Tried different cupcakes but the mango vanilla cupcake at Bea's is so far the best thing I've ever tasted! It's the best company for a warm sunny day and a cup of coffee/tea of your choice. The take-always are way cheaper than eat-in, £10 for 4 cupcakes is certainly a very good deal. The red velvet one tasted alright. While I indulged myself for the cupcake, I can't take my eyes off the triple chocolate cake they served near the cashier at reception. I kept thinking of getting it after my cupcake but I was too late when it came to the last piece of cake they have for today. I will return just to have a spoonful of that beauty. The coffee tastes not bad at all. But the best thing they seem to be good at serving is the afternoon tea. I went to the upper floor and the staff told me it was specially booked for high tea only and I caught a brief look at the set of sandwiches, scones and sweet cakes they were serving. It's for £19 per person and they looked busy on a sunday afternoon. I love the inner area of Bea's. Each table is furnished with a cute little bouquet of flower in a mini jam jar. Sitting here and looking outside while sipping your hot tea and devouring your cakes is the best feeling that you have to experience in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Mango vanilla cupcake and red velvet cupcake are my favs!
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Mango vanilla cupcake and red velvet cupcake are my favs!
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

Uz1yatFyIrNby-3LkrMykw.text: I do adore Bea's and I am a bit of a fanboy(girl) here since I got to meet the fabulous - and rather gorgeous - Bea!  That story is a good one as it involves an Chocco Elite Walking tour, a bit of chocolate hobnobbing (see what I did there?!) slash networking and then being invited to sit as a last-min judge for the International Chocolate Awards. Two. Whole. Days. Of. Chocolate.... Nyommm...I could say more but I run the risk of making you all jealous and mouth-watery - even more so than this lovely little tea joint might. What really stands out here is the decor and attention to detail. Really, one couldn't ask for much more. Well, apart from stonking cake, which they also do. Yay Bea's!

x67zi1x6T2AhLuxv8rjfgg.text: Stopped by on the spot for a last minute birthday cake for my colleague. The selection was good, considering I didn't preorder. The prices were a bit steep, and I ended up spending 40 quid for a 16" vanilla cheesecake topped with brownies.Couple minor things: the topping on the brownie cheesecake is normally supposed to be a mix of their brownies, and blondies, creating variety.  This cake only had the blondies, which was okay. The cake also looked like it had been through a bumpy car ride, and the sides had scraped off here and there. It's still edible, but for 40  quid it should be damn cute. The staff was super sweet, but apparently they don't do writing on cakes at this location. You can take your cake up to their other store for the decorating (no thanks). 4 stars because my coworkers absolutely loved the taste, and it was quite amazing for no pre-ordered. Another plus - you can order with just 24 hours advance (not minimum of 2-3 days I've seen elsewhere (see Hummingbird Bakery)).

aKJ_nGGmU4WM_jHVoiNrPQ.text: Cozy spot for a yummy Triple Chocolate Cake and an Earl Grey break. Sit upstairs for a good people watching. Warm welcome and attentive staff.

7jEHS8cWutDQbNhdXntWpA.text: Was able to reserve afternoon tea for two the day of and had a lovely experience. Everything was delicious! Definitely a bit more modern than your typical afternoon tea but definitely a fun change of pace. The woman who helped us was great! She even suggested we check out Camden and was just helpful all around helpful. Will definitely be back.

lXQnXcrGqDRTgHlfKa-x3w.text: My friend who lived in London for a while has nothing but good things to say about Bea's of Bloomsbury. So during my short visit to London, I made sure Bea's made it to my itinerary. We went at about 5PM, generally non-peak hour and no one was waiting so we were served right away. We ordered right away and our server was extremely rude to us. He assumed that we did not understand the menu and insisted that we order something other than what we wanted. We had to explain to him several times that we do not want to order what he suggested. After finally getting our order straight, we were supposed to  be seated however we had to sit in an undesirable corner on the first floor. They did not even try to get us better seats on the second floor. I thought maybe the food could make up for the rude service but the  food tasted pretty average. I had better english teas else where. Bottom line, I would not come back here during my next London visit and I don't think you should spend your money here for below average service and average food.

7yJafB9VszjdJ_1gj1Bo8Q.text: Service more than poor, everything overpriced, cleanliness inexistant. Just avoid. The coffee was average, the peanut jelly slice over done and the waiters seem to be too afraid of their boss to think straight.

mpeJc_fohxmfiaI36_RWXA.text: As part of my cupcake trials, we stopped in here to pick up a few cupcakes for office tea time.We picked the red velvet and the peanut butter chocolate. The red velvet was pretty bland and a bit dry. The icing was a good level of sweetness and a good texture. The peanut butter cupcake was much tastier. The chocolate in the cupcake was distinct and the saltiness of the peanut butter frosting was not over whelming. The place was pretty busy and the staff seemed pretty swamped. I wanted to get so much more out of this place because I have been to a number of Bea's events. I suppose I'll just have to come back for a proper afternoon tea or lunch.

g0YLx_rCUoH0I79O-Khm6g.text: Tourist trap. Neither the tea or the baked goods are good. And its very uncomfortable sitting there. We got a table right beside the kitchen and it was super hot. Hard pass.

gLI5AEhINujENVM4qJ__0w.text: Some tasty coffees and cupcakes here. The peanut butter frosting on the chocolate cupcakes is so light it's almost whipped, and while the cake itself isn't super moist, it does its job well enough.On the flip side, the latte I downed was some top-notch caffeine.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Cool upholstery upstairs
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Free sugar cubes!
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter and chocolate cupcake

bajBoPgt1K3kvZg717ouNA.text: Bea's is a delightful place to pop into if you're around St. Paul's. The selection is vast and the cupcake displays are adorable. I came on a Wednesday around lunchtime and the line was fairly long but it moved quickly. A man before me snatched up the entire loaf of bread that I wanted a piece of so instead I went with a scone and some hot chocolate. Their scones are a perfect combination of flaky and soft. The jam and clotted cream comes in tiny jars that you can take home afterwards. I probably wouldn't order the hot chocolate again only because it tastes like the stuff you can get at any corner coffee shop. Lovely experience overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Hot chocolate and scone with cream and jam

0zHjkd5CPZL7Q8tG8YLY7w.text: This location is in One New Change shopping mall over looking St Paul's. Really great location. However, shop itself is not very comfortable. Though there are two levels, it is long and narrow and the lay out makes you feel a bit squished. As soon as you walk in, you find yourself at the end of a line. You have to order downstairs. The cup cakes here look very enticing with thick and perfect icing. I opted for a duffin which is a cross between a donut and a muffin. I have to say it was delicious! Bea's is known for its afternoon tea and the prices are quite reasonable, starting from 19 pounds. Most of the seatings are upstairs and at one end of which, you have a view of St Paul's. If you can get a table there, it makes for a great experience. I definitely want to try another location for a proper afternoon tea.

zy1EE0glP7h6NuKvL1wMqA.text: Right opposite my workplace.  DANGEROUS! But onyl serves a limited amount of salad and it's all so carby. Which is not what I want especially when I'm trying avoid the 2pm slump. Anyways, I've mainly taken away and the chai latte has been hit and miss, sometimes, its great, but sometimes, it's a bit cold. So i wasn't too impressed, also i ate in once and they forgot to bring a salad...But, the cupcakes are really yummy, and the frosting, god, its the only frosting I like. it's not stiff, or too sweet, especially the pb & J cupcake, it's so light. Usually I've a substance girl, as in I love cake more frosting, I think decoration is unnecessary but I'd happily have bea's frosting! That is a feat alone!Top tip: if you have a blackhouse card (Grill on the market members) you get 10% off! WIN

qj2rsKSwcX2UhUi1oxkAAw.text: Had I not been to Bea's of Bloomsbury in Farringdon (and loved it) I would have given this place at least an extra star. My expectations were high, really high. When you walk you immediately you sense that this place is not the same, the cakes are not as a attractive and the staff while attentive, seem out of sync.  We got various drinks/cakes and nothing wow'ed us, it was all alright.  The shop itself has an upstairs part which is lovely and beautifully decorated.  This place has sooo much potential. I hope they make some changes to bring it up to par with the other one I've been to..

UGKIt9djxARx_X1-X3TvYA.text: I enjoyed a delicious afternoon tea here with friends visiting from the States. Thomas A. recommended it so I knew it had to be good. I has a so-so experience at their Holborn location but I was willing to give them another go.And I am so glad I did. The brownie bites, passion fruit flavored marshmallows and cupcakes rocked my socks! The accompanied sandwiches were delicious. They even substituted the tea for coffee and it was a good cuppa.I returned another day and enjoyed a great iced coffee and yummy cupcake. I left in a dream-like state and forgot to pay! I remembered while on the train and with a pink face I returned the next day to pay. They were very appreciative of my honesty and I was, well, very appreciative of them being so understanding.Now I definitely need to come back for lunch soon. That too looked as delicious as their cakes and brownies.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Lovely cupcakes and cakes.

1E7e_E2AVGrGCoGChGp-ug.text: I first tasted a Bea's cupcake at 2010's Taste of London. From that moment on I would forever be a fan!I raved to anyone that would listen how amazing the cupcakes were. Everyone I raved to went and loved it (LOOK AT TYN R's review). I referred sooooo many people there because I love it so much and was told I can get a free cupcake of choice (which I've yet to collect, but can I say this makes me love them MORE). I must say this ranks as one of my fave places for Afternoon Tea.  Everything is delicious. I'm not a fan of marshmallows but I could eat a bazillion of theirs. Typing this up I'm pondering when is the next time I can go. Everything I've ever had from Bea's is superbly divine and for the prices they charge, what is there to complain about!!!I love whimsical floating tea pots. When it gets dark and the tea pots are illuminated everything feels so magical. I love the decor as a whole, everything works well together. I've been when they have been quite dead and extremely busy and like any other restaurant you notice the difference in service. But I really wouldn't hold it against them. There are no faults! Actually, my only complaint is not being able to book a table during the weekend if you aren't having afternoon tea. But that just shows how popular they are. NEED MORE BRANCHES OF BEA'S!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Pistachio & Chocolate cupcake *mmmmmm*
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

uD_M-0wYS0DymISrNEiB5w.text: The place's decor is super nice. I came here after being recommended by the Hotel Conicerge and it was a great choice! Loved my British tea and the croissant and jam was lovely. The eggs Benedict were also super filling. Overall, I really loved this spot. Would totally return for high tea next during my next trip!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Croissants
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. View from the venue

HTNuLooHufGUUk-U8c-X3w.text: (3.5 stars) Gluten-friendly hi-tea. Delicious dessert items. Very beautiful presentation. Overall everything tasted good. I made a reservation for gluten-free high-tea on a Thursday afternoon. It wasn't very busy.Menu:Each sandwich had a generous amount of cream cheese that day which I probably shouldn't have eaten since my stomach is sensitive to dairy. I found there were too many sweet items. I couldn't finish all the desserts but I did eat the scone which was warm and delicious. The clotted cream came in a package which was disappointing. I'd come back and maybe ask them leave off the cream cheese. I would also come back with a friend who likes sweet more than savory.Venue:Great atmosphere especially if you are alone, like I was. Central location. Good views of the street from upstairs if you enjoy people watching. Service:The staff was very accommodating and allowed me to replace the avocado sandwich (avocado allergy). Fast service. Very friendly.

e8qjSYp5O102kDp6pupRQg.text: Tea was good but the scones were stale and the clotted cream was not fresh. If you're looking for a traditional afternoon tea spot, keep looking.

qjGn9AJlSxE30y_auKrG9Q.text: This place is pretty crowded, but enjoyable. We ordered cream tea -- which came with plenty of clotted cream, but not quite enough jam. Tea was delicious, ambiance was great. The other baked goods looked very enticing, too.Everyone else was pretty well-dressed, but it could be that folks came directly from work.

T60RlYocco6kU3n21vniLA.text: The place is tight. There wasn't a huge variety when I went. I didn't think what I tried was fresh. But I have had visited farridgton shop and the pastries were really good.

WEs7RfjDk7efX5Pj2Ay2kQ.text: If you're in the area and desperate for afternoon tea just drink out of a toilet than come here. The service was lacking, the sandwiches are mostly bread filled with lies. The tea was bland and had no depth. The cream, jam, and pastries were generic grocery store brand made by a man with his souls ripped out by his former love and no longer sees the light. The church was cool to walk by though.

2qexDuHI_MoKQI_JmGValg.text: Stopped by to get a break from the cold weather and ordered some earl grey tea (didn't do the full afternoon tea experience). Giving five stars for the location, friendly staff who went out of their way to give me local recommendations (one even came back to my table after writing down a restaurant's address for me), and the fact that I got a full pot of delicious tea, cream, and sugar cubes for two pounds rather than simply a small prepared cup (which is what I expected for that price).

ZsjDQ56z1NegC_mdoi1oAQ.text: Oh Bea's. Oh Bea's. Oh dear Bea's.It seems a bit off, you sees. I booked a midweek afternoon tea with my mother thinking Bea's would be a nice treat. I'm sad to report I just wasn't that impressed. At all. First, this entire shop is in need of a good scrubbing and polish. Despite its fancy digs behind One New Change, the interior somehow seems worn, chipped, a bit grimy and frankly, in need of some polish. Fingerprints on the case, bathroom a bit divey. The good news? This can all be fixed in a few hours, Bea. I highly recommend putting some focus here, it's desperately needed given the price point. Because if I come in to a shop and pay £16 per person for an afternoon tea, I'd expect baseline level of "very good." I'm not expecting a hotel caliber tea experience but I would expect things to be in good order. The one pot of tea was fine, but nothing memorable. The sandwiches seemed liked they'd been sitting a long while (soggy), and the cupcakes were very nice, but the flavors offered to us we didn't pick...so we ended up with something lemon (which I don't like) and something fruity (again, wouldn't have been my first choice). With such a great selection of cupcakes, perhaps let the tea guests select which ones they'd enjoy? The service was nice, although it took an eon to get the check and once we did get it no one ever came back for it so I finally had to just go down and pay for it myself so we could get out of there. Maybe an off day? Perhaps. Oh Bea's, it was our time to shine and unfortunately the dullness of the shop and presentation just left me wanting more.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea break!
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

K1CLDu9urRZ7oIDXZWyUig.text: Bea's of Bloomsbury and Primrose Bakery are my faaaav places to get cupcakes in London. And there are a lot of chose from due to the big cupcake boom of 2011.Beas of Bloomsbury creates cupcakes with thick buttery icing and dense cakey bottoms.This particular chain is always packed and this is the first time I've actually gotten a seat in there. We ordered and paid at the till and sat at on the ground floor next to the window. It was dark since the lights weren't turned on above us and damp from the rain outside. It's also quite a small space and we were right next to the kitchen so staff busied in and out by our table. It wasn't the best atmosphere (comparable to somewhere like costa coffee) but the cupcakes totally made up for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Duche Le leche and coconut cupcakes

aCiZOy2ckf2ht_la8VkfQg.text: Afternoon tea in London was a priority for me, and while there is no shortage of tea here it seemed many of the options were overpriced.  Bea's isn't cheap but worth every pound.  It's located near St. Paul's and not far from the Tower (which was more interesting to me).  The space is quite nice, there are even a few tables outside.  The staff is extremely friendly and I credit one of them for letting me know about Camden Market which I likely wouldn't have found on my own.  Back to the tea, we opted to add prosecco with our tea which was a good call.  I almost don't know if I can drink tea without it.  The sandwiches and scones that accompanied the beverages were lovely as well.  Even if tea isn't a priority, I recommend stopping by.

JaccFfwTyiqaZSB4fANB3g.text: We decided to go for an alternative Christmas meal at work this year and opted for Beas afternoon tea. The staff made it easy to book and accommodated a few different allergies (nut, gluten and vegetarian).At £29 excluding tip it came to a pricey meal out and didn't include any crackers, Christmas decorations etc however we all came away full, satisfied and most of us with doggy bags of leftover cake! The afternoon tea at £25 includes 3 sandwiches, 3 brownies, a cupcake, a marshmallow, a scone with clotted cream and jam and of course a choice of tea (hot choco or coffee is also an alternative) . For an extra fiver you can upgrade to 'gold afternoon tea' which adds a macaroon and a mini bottle of fizz (worth it in my opinion). Sandwiches were really good - highlights being the cream cheese & walnut. There was also one with mozzarella in and one with salami but I think they mix this up q fair bit. The bread that they used was a nice salty focaccia which made it different to the normal finger sandwiches you get. On to the scone - most of them looked good but mine was a little dry and over baked, however there was plenty of jam and clotted cream to slather on top and with tea and fizz to wash it down it was more than bearable. There was a lotta sweet stuff - the brownies were lovely and rich however the blondie was disappointing; just sugar with no white chocolate. The marshmallows were homemade and obviously super sweet but not my thing. These came in different flavours but I got a plain one so it was a bit boring. For the main event: each cake stand had several cupcakes of different flavours. I had a lovely chocolate and pistachio one which was moist and rich. The only odd thing was the cream on top which had a funny texture. It was also a shame you couldn't choose the cupcake you wanted from the menu. Finally - I went for the black vanilla tea which was delicious. Not too sweet but didn't need milk. It went perfectly with the cakes. However don't expect too much choice. I think there were only 8 teas available. Overall a lovely team outing (we were nearly there for 2 hours although service was efficient). I will be back for a cup of tea and cake but not for afternoon tea - I've had better in London I'm afraid!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

gAuVc_rc6RbwTwyKFoedZg.text: Scones were good, sandwich not so much, bread was old and chewy. Service was quite unfriendly though...

nbTAGrsxJ57p0QSlOuTxbg.text: I was very excited to do afternoon tea in London and Bea's was highly recommended, we're in London after all how can you not have afternoon tea? This place is cute, not very big, highly recommended getting reservation.  The entrance has sweets and treat for take away, if you don't want to have the full experience.  There was three of us, we recieved an assortment of sandwiches, (tuna, pulled pork, smoked cheese) scones was delightful with yummy cream and jam ( this was the highlight of the afternoon) and assortments of sweets from marshmallows, brownies, cupcakes.   Everything was ok, nothing extraordinary.  As mentioned before the scone cream and jam was delouse, I would come back for those.  We all choose a creamy earl grey which was good.  Overall, it was a good experince.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

cggvYVl4tVFgCFQ3ByEs6A.text: I wish I had seen the yelp reviews before making a reservation for high tea at this establishment. We were excited to go somewhere that we could dress in a casual manner since we were out sightseeing. This did not mean we were not willing to pay for a nice high tea. Once we were seated we observed dirty glasses dirty cups no napkins and we were not even given a fork during the entire time of our visit. The food and service were mediocre at best. Overpriced for what we received. If you want high tea go back to your hotel and get dressed up and simply go somewhere fancy. This establishment is not recommended.

kLt1cMoPukM3tay6iKwUxw.text: Verdict: When afternoon tea not need to cost an arm and leg Bea is a lovely place to be at!Pros:- Fab location, looking at St P!- Cosy and intimate settings.- Regardless of the size, this bea is tiny, I always been lucky to get a sit and never been rushed out to free a table!- Attentive and accommodating staff.- Still very good (but not as good-valued as before) fulfilling afternoon tea!- Cupcakes: Lemon vanilla or carrot cake are to die for!Cons:- Pricing seems now a little out of whack: Afternoon tea price gone up almost 6£ in less than a year!- I for one have difficulties with pulled pork let alone on an afternoon tea tray!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

B1BjflJlElDjiE7-MFmJaQ.text: I was at the Bloomsbury location today hoping for high tea but the server didn't know what high tea was and said they only serve afternoon tea. Don't let their website fool you. What you get is a totally different class of cafe, not any better than Starbucks. Poor quality and service.  The restroom alone can tell you alot. Not recommended.

KdAwEcgeTjLvVySI5zGpvQ.text: Lovely little shop with lots of cupcake choices.  We tried several and to be honest they look great but it lacking on the taste side...  The staff is friendly and the shop almost all the ingredients to make them stunning...

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

B2qmupeAJYaKn8Pg_GFrpQ.text: I am not gonna lie I was disappointed with Bea's of Bloomsbury. We had the duffin with Nutella at the Farringdon shop 8 months ago and loved, loved, loved it! So we decided to go back to Bea's but thought it would be nice to sit down and have a drink, hence why we ended at Bea's of Bloomsbury. It was about 2pm and we were ready to order the infamous duffin, but to our disappointment they had no nutella ones left! I settled on the jam one and whilst it was ok the hot chocolate wasn't great, too rich and the service could have been better. It seems the team is young and inexperienced so the service felt a bit chaotic. They are however friendly and this isn't the staff's fault if perhaps they need a tad more training.

XXmC_GJTUVScdmnYitdDQw.text: Service is relaxed but very friendly. Sandwiches are yummy. Try the avocado with cream cheese croissant.

7xZmcOZ2uLxS8X8UPAqGRA.text: I came here for afternoon tea with a group of four, after some friends recommended it. The location is near St. Paul's but it was a little odd that it was part of an outdoor mall. The tea house was cute on the inside and narrow with an upstairs section where we were seated. If you're looking to have a proper or traditional afternoon tea, don't come here. It is a more casual or cafe style take on afternoon tea. That being said, the sandwiches were delicious and were served on a thick focaccia type of bread. The scone was amazing too and I loved their clotted cream! I don't have any complaints with the tea (English breakfast) either except our waitress was never around to ask for more hot water. The desserts were what I was most disappointed in. They served us an array of cupcakes, brownies, and meringues, which were all equally unimpressive. At 20 something £s, I did not find the experience quite worth it. Although, it is a much cheaper alternative to afternoon tea in London if you desire something more casual and filling. Just don't come here expecting a formal tea experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
